column4: hey, i'm running dapper on a rather long-in-tooth machine (mobile p3 @1.2 ghz w/256mb ram) and was wondering where i could go within GNOME to kill some apps and otherwise streamline my system
i found a 'services' tab in system, but it was of limited use
what exactly are you trying to kill? you mean unneeded services/background processes?
basically, yes.  i haven't any trouble with my desktop, but my laptop lags quite a bit under normal loads
have you tried running top (or htop) or a GUI equivalent thereof? Usually Linux is pretty good at not wasting CPU cycles with sleeping processes
chances are the lag is due to a slow video card
or non-hardware accellerated video drivers :)
damn this gma830 all to hell
haven't run top, or anything like that, but i can see how my antiquated gpu could be causing problems
hehe, i see. Unfortunately X is quite sensitive to slow GPUs, in part due to its inefficient design and in part due to 99% of all drivers for X being software
well, that explains much. just ran top and everything seems to be fine (averaging about 12 percent cpu load)
just to illustrate, when i was running the nv driver on my box with an nVidia Gefore4, my memory usage was around 500megs. When I switched to the binary driver, the memory usage almost went down 50%
my guess is the nv driver used regular system ram instead of video ram! :(
wow.
so yeah, drivers make a big diff
especially if you run something heavyweight, like KDE or gnome
have you considered xfce? might be just what your laptop needs :)
apt-get install xubuntu-desktop, I believe
consider it considered, my friend
well, give it a spin. if you want a preview, check the ubuntu website
